description: An adaptation of extenuātiōn-, the oblique stem of the Latin extenuātiō (“a thinning or diminishing”, “rarefaction”; rhetoric “a lessening”, “diminution”, “extenuation”), noun of action from extenuō (“I thin, reduce, or diminish”). Equivalent to extenuate +‎ -ion. Compare the French exténuation.

definitionGroups.group: (countable and uncountable) The action of extenuating; extenuated condition.

entries.meaning: The action or process of making or becoming thin; an instance of this; a shrunken condition; leanness, emaciation.
examples: This mightily helpeth the extenuation of members.

entries.meaning: (of air, obsolete) Making less dense; rarefaction.
examples: Winds proceed from extenuation of the Air, by the Sun.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) The action or process of making slender or diminishing in bulk; an instance of this.
examples: All Dilatation is some degree of Extenuation.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) The action of making less or weak; and instance of this; a weakening, impoverishment. Also, mitigation (of blame or punishment).
examples: The saide citie is much decaid…not a little to the extenuacion of that part of this realme.

entries.meaning: The action of representing (something) as slight and trifling; underrating; an instance of this, a plea to this end; a modification in terms.
examples: Sometimes…wee humble ourselves lower than there is cause…And no lesse well doth God take these submisse extenuations of our selves.

entries.meaning: (rhetoric, obsolete) A figure in which a term is used which, in contrast with the more fitting term it supplants, understates or seeks to diminish the significance of something.
examples: We call him the Disabler or figure of Extenuation.

entries.meaning: The action of lessening, or seeking to lessen, the guilt of (an offence or fault) by alleging partial excuses; and instance or means of doing this; a plea in mitigation of censure.
examples: Extenuation, by which the Crime, that seemed great, is made lesse.

entries.meaning: (US, humorous, in the plural as “extenuations”) Thin garments.
examples: They were clad in silken extenuations from the throat to the feet.
